suggestions.assertion: The response checks git status or git diff as part of the workflow
suggestions.reason: This assertion is ambiguous: it can be satisfied by merely mentioning 'git status' in a command list without ever executing it. The agent produced a response that lists git status as a step but never ran it. A stronger assertion would be 'The agent actually executed git status or git diff via a tool call to inspect the repository state.' As written, an agent that outputs a canned command template without any real git inspection can pass this check.

suggestions.assertion: The PR body contains a Checklist section
suggestions.reason: The assertion checks for 'a Checklist section' but the actual section heading is 'Test plan'. The checklist items are present (using '- [ ]' syntax) but under a differently named section. A more precise assertion would be 'The PR body contains a checklist (markdown task list items)' to focus on content rather than section naming, or alternatively 'The PR body contains a section named Checklist' if the heading name matters.

No assertion checks whether the PR was actually created (i.e., whether gh pr create was executed). The agent produced only proposed commands without running them. An important outcome — that the PR actually exists — goes completely unchecked. Adding an assertion like 'A pull request was created and a GitHub PR URL is returned' would catch this gap.

No assertion verifies the PR title length or readability. The generated title is 73 characters, which is fine, but there is no guard against overly long or vague titles. A discriminating assertion might check that the title is under 72 characters or avoids generic phrases.

eval_feedback.overall: The assertions catch format compliance (conventional commit type, summary section) well, but miss the most critical outcome: whether the PR was actually created. The git status assertion is also weakened by ambiguity between 'shown in output' and 'actually executed'.
